Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned useful lab techniques such as ISH, RNAi, and reporter gene fusion. I also learned a lot about embryogenesis and the central dogma of biology.
I learned how to write a research paper, a very important skill and I am so thankful that we had the opportunity to work so closely with help to get it done.
The role genetics plays in our day-to-day life and our development. Also developed how to write and analyze professional scientific papers.

I learned a more consolidated, detailed version of genetics than I had understood in high school, as well as major developmental processes, the interactions between genetics, development, and medicine, and how cells can develop a full, complex, multicellular organism.
I learned about various genetic techniques and concepts as well as some developmental processes.
Research design, genetics, cell development, mutations

Learned about the general pathway of development for organisms and how development processes are conserved across different species. In the latter half of the course, I learned about genetics beyond the Mendelian standpoint, discussing sex-linkage, recombination, etc.

Information about ways we study genetics, Mendelian and non-Mendelian genetics, information about diseases and how they are passed down, learning how to read scientific papers and write a basic scientific research proposal
This course gave me a basic understanding of genetics and development. It was also a good introduction to the skills necessary for understand scientific writing.
I learned a lot about both genetics and developmental biology, and the relationship between the two. I also learned how to evaluate experiments, as well as design my own through a research proposal.

I gained a better insight into the field of genetics --- mostly, in terms of experimental techniques and perturbations I could theoretically carry out in a lab to study a gene. The course taught genetics in the context of developmental processes, which I found fascinating because I'd never been exposed to developmental biology before. I also learned how to write a research proposal, predict phenotypes of experiments based on hypothetical experimental data, and design hypothetical experiments.

Basic genetics and development. There were a lot of very specific systems and examples that we had to memorize. While the genetics concepts followed from high school biology knowledge, the development information was relatively new.
I learned about several concepts in genetics and developmental biology.
I learned a foundation in developmental biology and genetics.
This class gave a decent overview of basic developmental concepts and genetics. These ideas were solidified with detailed examples as well as experimental practices.
I learned how genetics applies to disease research and the development of the diseases themselves.

This course covered basic aspects of genetics and development. I feel that doing the research proposal and learning about all of the different types of studies people do in labs has changed the way I think about biology research, especially in genetics, and I think it was valuable in that way.
Fundamental knowledge of developmental biology and genetics
Basic knowledge of developmental biology and genetic technologies.

I got a refresher of a lot of the genetics knowledge I learned in AP Biology in high school, and I gained more detailed knowledge about genetics, a variety of the developmental processes that must occur for normal development, and many changes that lead to abnormal development.

I learned about various genetic studies and methods such as genome-wide association studies. I learned how these methods are used to study diseases. I also learned about the development of the embryo and how various induction factors and cytoplasmic inequivalence can help guide development of embryos.

I learned information regarding development for the first half of the class and genetics for the second half. Also I learned how to write research proposals in an organized and clear manner and read research papers.
Learned about development and some basic genetics concepts.

how to apply "the facts" and not just regurgitate information
it was challenging but oftentimes more straightforward than I thought if I did not overthink it
I learned basic knowledge about genetics and developing bodies and cells from this course.
You learn all about the basics behind the development of organisms and the genetics that runs this development.
I developed further my scientific thinking and experiment-planing skills, and I also learned through a step-by-step process how to write a grant proposal.
I learned more about general developmental processes and genetic mechanisms
I learned about the mechanisms through which genes control fundamental life processes. I also learned the means by which development unfolds in different living organisms.

I learned an exceptional amount about genetics, development, and the role of genetics in development. I also learned about how to tie in past information from Bio 101 and 102 to understand concepts in 103.
Greater understanding of genetics and developmental biology and how to think critically as a scientist.
I learn different ways to test how a gene functions in an organism.

I learned how to use various genetic infrastructure that is available on the world wide web including genome searches and database searching. I learned how to write a research proposal. We looked at genetics through the lens of specific systems. Other than that, I really just memorized a bunch of information that became even more confuddled after taking the quiz and the exams because the questions were so damn unclear.
I further developed my ability to simplify thinking about complex developmental systems and their relation to the central dogma.

I got a glimpse of what the field of developmental biology can be. I really come to enjoy developmental biology. I learned so much about the tools developmental biologists use to study related process.
I learned a lot about genetics and developments.
Research paper wriitng
Mutations and genetics and development

I learned about many developmental processes, including how they relate to specific pathways and scientific experiments. I also learned about genetics and how it relates to development. Importantly, I learned how to go about designing an experiment in this field.
I rote-momorized facts for the quizzes and forgot them immediately.

I learned a lot about development and genetics as the course title indicates. The course went into a good amount of detail regarding the specific developmental processes that occur as all organisms develop from fertilization. Most of the genetics in this course was just a brush on genetics covered in high school, but it was still nice to relearn things that I had forgotten.
Learned in depth about developmental biology and also how to analyze papers on this subject.
I learned to analyze and interpret data in a time constraint.
How to connect developmental biology to genetic diversity.
General knowledge about certain genetic and development processes. How to structure research proposals.
I developed skills relating to genetics.
Knowledge about genetics and development.
Really none at all.
Kind of learned about very specific development processes. However information was incredibly poorly and sometimes just incorrectly presented.
Loved this class. I learned so much about genetics and laboratory techniques.
I learned about development and the actual science behind it as well as the mechanisms used to study development.
A strong foundational knowledge of development and genetics as well as knowledge on experimentation techniques and proposal writing.
I developed an understanding of basic genetics and development.
Applying concepts learned
I learned a lot about fruit flies
I gained a lot of information about developmental biology content and techniques, experiments, pathways, and some genetics. I also learned how to use some online biology research resources.
I honestly didn't learn much. Considering the amount of time it takes to complete the homeworks and study for the quizzes, this is sad.
More insight on genetics overall.
Genetics and development knowledge
I learned a great deal about concepts in genetics, development, and experimental thinking.
I learned some facts about genetics and development.
I learned about genetics and development.

Biol 103 is a great introductory course for understanding the mechanisms of genetics and development, especially with attention to the vast diversity and unity of life. I also developed a lot of critical reading and thinking skills with regards to formulating and interrogating a scientific hypothesis (we read a lot of landmark scientific papers, and the homework in the class is centered on a step-wise approach to generating a scientific proposal).
More about the drosophilia embryo development process, and genetic analysis.
Deeper understanding of genetics and specific mechanisms. I also learnt about catch it, break it, and move it experiments.

I got better at reading scientific papers (both decoding individual papers and wading through entries on Pubmed) and designing and critiquing scientific experiments. I developed a foundational understanding of genetics and (especially human) developmental processes
I learned a lot about genetics and how organisms develop.
I learned more about genetics and different molecular methods.
How to memorize very specific genetics examples. Theres truly very little interesting stuff, this should be a whole semester course to make any sense
I learned a lot about the mechanisms behind developmental biology
I learned the basics of development.

Basic foundation of the principles of genetics and development, such as limb development, the stages of embryo development, transposons, genetic editing, along with an additional lecture on biotechnology and cancer.

I learned about genetics & development at a very basic level. I didn't learn about any concept in particular in depth, because the professors never bothered to explain them well nor provide enough information about a certain concept. In addition, any attempt to ask questions to gain a deeper understanding was met with a more confusing and unsatisfactory answer, or "you don't need to know that for this course".
I learned about key developmental processes in humans and in several model organisms. I learned to write a short research proposal.
The biggest knowledge that I developed in this course was how microscopic developmental processes interact and work together to influence macroscopic processes.

I learned about the development of organisms and plants starting from fertilization and going all the way through the life cycle. An important skill that I developed was my ability to write scientifically. Writing a scientific paper was extremely worthwhile, and I was very proud to see my final product.
Generally, an understanding of developmental biology, and the complexity of processes involved in it.
I developed a solid background in developmental biology and genetics.

I think the course's material is extremely interesting and Professor Irish is a good lecturer. I think sometimes, the quiz questions were asked very differently from how the material was presented, which could be a bit confusing--that could be fixed if we talked a little more about what about the material to focus on (i.e. in what way we should think about applying the concepts).

Strengths: the topic itself is very engaging and interesting. The one weakness will have to be the time given for the quizzes and final. Each question on the quiz requires thorough thinking and analysis and the time given just isn't enough to do that.

I prefer the weekly quiz structure of BIOL 101/103 to the midterm format of 102/104, as it forces constant review of the material, but I greatly preferred BIOL 101's structure of Monday quizzes and Wednesday homework to the reverse in BIOL 103. It's a small detail but I felt it made a huge difference in how manageable or unmanageable the course was. I also felt like certain complicated concepts like pattern formation and transgenics were not fully and clearly explained in either section or lecture (only finally in enrichment), and that in some cases, this was because it was unclear which details we needed to know.

Strength: The psets encouraged learning and insight
Weakness: The quizzes and psets can be challenging and stressful

The course felt like BIOL 101 in that it was well organized. The quizzes made sure that we knew what to expect on the final, and all deadlines were clear for the homework assignments. I did feel that sometimes more complicated concepts (like epistasis) were rushed, and some quiz questions were difficult solely because the wording was weird or purposefully tricky, but the time crunch meant there was no time to ask someone for clarification. I also started out enjoying the homework assignment (even though it took me a couple weeks and therefore lots of re-writing to chose a gene and process to write about), and then slowly started to dislike it when I was made to realize that what had seemed like an open-ended exploratory assignment was not.

There was high variability in TF grading for homework and quizzes. I often did not receive clear feedback for deductions on assignments.

The quizzes were poorly worded and misleading. They were tailored to very specific aspects of biology. Often answers expected knowledge that was not covered in lecture (based on my own experience and the experiences of many of my peers.

A strength of this course is that the material is interesting and engaging, especially when we discuss real-world applications and what kinds of diseases or conditions can occur through errors in development and genetics.
A weakness is that the course does not provide sufficient help in terms of teaching students to read and discuss scientific papers, and in terms of supplying practice questions for what I would consider "trickier" questions in this specific biology module.

Strengths: generally well-taught, good diversity of material
Weaknesses: scientific paper is a good idea, but should be more specific or narrow in focus
Interesting content and somewhat fair quizzes, although felt a bit rushed over some topics

This course is a good overview of the principles of genetics as well as development, but it tends to lack the basic information necessary to clarify big questions. For example, many of the developmental processes that were taught were animal-specific, but sometimes this wasn't completely clear during the lecture. This course also seemed to have discrepancies between the material taught and the quiz questions, which made it tricky for students to do well even after studying the material given.

Professor Irish taught well & Professor Lin is a great course coordinator who helps ensure the modules all run smoothly. Piazza was a really great tool for asking questions and beginning discussions. However, the weekly quizzes were usually a time crunch so they were harder than expected, and the final was definitely a time crunch for me. I think that if we had practice questions, that would have helped a lot.

Strength - learning interesting biology. Weakness - it is too specific. I wish I learned more about the broader scope of biology rather than random signaling pathways. The quizzes were designed to be tricky, not helpful

Professor Irish is a good instructor, and her decision to ground genetics in the context of developmental biology made the course material engaging, refreshing, and interesting with each lecture. She also emphasized experimental techniques and predicting phenotypes from experiments, which I had never been trained to do before in a class setting, and absolutely adored. For example, given information X and Y, we had to predict what would happen if Y was knocked out, or what would happen if X were ectopically expressed in a Y mutant. This kind of thinking is valuable to any budding scientist, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. In terms of weaknesses, the homework sounds cool --- writing a research proposal to study a gene! --- but it's so open-ended to the point of a vague nature that most students spent 6-8 hours a week writing the new section of the proposal because there were so many dead ends and false paths to be encountered. I think the homework could be better structured in the beginning (more guidance?) such that it does not disproportionately bog down a student's homework workload.

I found the distinction between memorizing and understanding the broader concepts of examples arbritrary and quite unclear. A clearer delineation of facts to memorize and examples to generally understand would improve the course experience for Bio 103ers. I found the quizzes to be quite stressful and time rushed. While discussion section journal club provided an interesting application of the topics in class, the expectations for the homework assignments varied substantially for each TF. 
However, overall I enjoyed Prof Irishs teaching style.
I learnt a lot in this course. I felt the developmental biology part was taught better than the genetics part.

The weaknesses of this course include a lot of assignments, that may take 18 hours a week, and do not have any relationship to the course being taught. Also, the lectures are very fast-paced and assume you have a strong background in genetics. The quizzes are not related to the lecture material as much as Biol 101-102, so the only way to do well on the quizzes is to know the tricks and be able to think very fast. But unfortunately, no sample questions or homework questions are given.

I like the organization of the course and the lectures were done in an order that made sense. The only thing is that some of the topics we covered seemed very specific to certain processes and we had to memorize specific aspects of them (such as knowing whether bicoid is concentrated posteriorly or anteriorly) which didnt seem entirely useful especially for a course that is suppposed to be an introductory course.

The weekly quizzes were good for making students accountable but unfortunately the quiz content was unncessarily specific and seemed as though they were designed to trip students up rather than test for understanding.
This course is well taught and the quizzes are perfectly do-able, though the final didn't match the difficulty level of the quizzes.

Professor talks very fast and the lecture slides themselves don't contain all of the information, so it was a bit challenging to get all of the details down for each of the experiments, processes, etc. The organization of the slides were also a bit confusing at times. However, the important concepts were covered in pretty good detail.
It was a good way to learn fundamentals of biology

Strengths are content (learn important techniques and scientific principles) and the homework assignments--really make you think about how to test different hypotheses. Weaknesses are lots of memorization, poorly written quizzes and tests that don't really assess your learning, and the homework can take a long time.
Poor preparation for quizzes

I wish the course were more engaging. I found that there were many times during lectures that I would stop paying attention or lose focus because the material wasn't really presented in an engaging way. I also wish we had practice questions for the final exam; instead, we were just expected to review the quizzes to get a sense of the format of the questions, but I think it would have been very helpful to have a practice exam at our disposal so we could truly get a feeling for the styles of questions on the exam and how long it would be, instead of just winging it when we got to the exam. 

I liked how our homework assignments were all parts of a grant proposal, with the final assignment culminating into a mini grant proposal, because I think that for any student interested in scientific research, being able to write a grant proposal is an essential skill to have. While the assignments were very condensed versions of what a grant proposal would actually entail, I think that it was good exposure to the general parts that go into a grant proposal. I also liked how we had weekly quizzes because it made me stay on top of the material and get a good sense of the parts that I struggled with more than others, so I could better study for the final exam and learn from the mistakes I made in certain aspects of the material.

Strengths: not too much work if you're familiar with scientific papers and are comfortable writing about science
Weakness: too brief and specific for certain aspects of genetics and development

One strength was learning how to write a research proposal, which I think is a very important skill for people who are interested in science. I wish we were given some practice quizzes/questions to prepare ourselves even more, especially because our homework did not directly pertain to specific lecture material.

The main weakness of this course are all the assesments. The quizzes are strange and quite difficult. The worst part is the homeworks. Truly, the homeworks for this class are the most poorly designed homeworks i have ever experienced at yale. The guidelines are somehow too narrow and too broad. Most people do alright on the hws but the greif stress and overall nightmare that these homeworks bring on are horrific.

Strengths: Prof. Irish usually moves at a good pace, got through a lot of important content. Prof. Lin is also great! 

Weaknesses: The homework assignments were a little too vague and sometimes it felt like not all expectations were laid out. Lecture was sometimes confusing and I wish that the study guides did more to go over the content of each lecture. My biggest issue with the class was the often vague wording on the quizzes. Sometimes I felt like I lost points just because interpreted poorly worded questions incorrectly. Lastly, I think the final is weighted way too heavily (equivalent to all quizzes combined??)

The lecture slides were at times poorly explained. I wished we spent more time on the slides that were a bit more technical and related 
to the more tricky open ended questions on quizzes... that way, we know what to focus on for the quizzes

I felt as though sometimes material in lecture was not presented in a clear way. There would be things that we would just quickly go over and I didn't fully understand them but felt nervous raising my hand in front of everyone to ask for clarification. I wish that we went over topics from class more in section instead of reading new papers.

strengths- the information was formatted and organized efficiently, where I felt each lecture built off the previous one.
Weaknesses- slides could have been more detailed, as it became hard to study for quizzes solely on the slides provided. Some slides were confusing on their importance.
It was overall very strong. Professor Irish is really a great lecturer.
I think the way the course is run is great. I appreciate that there is time for questions throughout the lecture.

The class was generally decently organized and I learned the material well. However, the research proposal project was a huge time drain and not particularly useful in any way, and I feel that we would have been better served by homework assignments which reinforced lecture material.

This course offers an a solid introduction to genetics and development. It is fairly comprehensive, and the content is generally interesting. Weaknesses of this course are the organization of the lectures, which often feel like they jump across multiple topics without clear reasons for why they are being covered in the same lecture. In addition, the course homework is essentially one assignment spread out over five weeks--this has both the advantage of helping you learn something new but also can take an inordinately large amount of time.

Weaknesses is that the lectures, homework assignments, and discussion sections all felt very disconnected and it felt like I was taking three separate courses instead of one. I would've liked practice questions before quizzes to get an idea of what the quizzes would be like (since the homework did not deal with the lecture material at all)
The lectures and lecture study guides are very well made but it could be better to have practice tests as well.

It would have been helpful to have more comprehensive study guides with the actual information that we were supposed to understand rather than broad overviews. That said, overall I thought it was organized well.
The homework assignments were too time consuming. The guidelines for the assignment could have been clearer.

There aren't any strengths of this course. The material is disorganized and explained very poorly. We brush over concepts that end up being the core of an exam and spend way too much time on topics that are never tested. The main concepts need to be emphasized. This course needs to be more like bio 101. Bio 101 had weekly quizzes, but they strung together everything so elegantly. Emphasize the most important topics that can be used to make us think more like scientists. the exams and quizzes were worded so poorly that you could never know what answer the instructor wanted. It seemed almost like an english class, everything was up to interpretation. Nothing seemed like it had a right answer. They were unfair in this way
Quiz content is tricky in wording -- should be made clearer.
The course is very organized and makes a lot of sense. I really dont have any complaints about the course because I really like the entire course including Professor Irish, Lin, and all the TAs.
I think the lectures are a little unorganized. Discussion sections were also kind not helpful, maybe it was just my TA.
No

Strengths: Very approachable teaching faculty

Weaknesses: Slides look hastily put together and are often unhelpful. More text on the slides would be preferred, rather than just having a single, very confusing, very complicated looking figure on each slide (which is frankly what most of the slides are!). NOT ENOUGH TIME ON THE QUIZZES. PLEASE, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD. WRITE SHORTER QUIZZES, OR ALLOT 20-25 MINUTES PER QUIZ. 15 MINUTES FOR THOSE THINGS WAS NOT FAIR TO STUDENTS WHO CAN'T WRITE QUICKLY AND DID NOT GIVE ADEQUATE TIME FOR STUDENTS TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR KNOWLEDGE! Some students need a few more minutes to get to the right answer than other students... they should have the opportunity to demonstrate their capabilities in a fair environment. 

The other thing is -- I appreciate the fact that this class has a lot of "getting students to see what real science looks like" -type of elements to it. But a balance must be struck between giving students adequate time during discussion section to get the help/review they need and introducing new (and even more confusing) content. The discussion sections are structured like "journal clubs," which is cool in some ways, but there were weeks where I was so lost on the content and really just would have appreciated a "recitation/review-style" section with some additional practice problems similar to what we see on quizzes.

The strengths of this course are rooted in its emphasis on the scientific process and learning not only about specific pathways/genes/molecules but also about experimental techniques that were used to understand them and can be used to discover more in the future. This was reinforced by section and the homework assignments. Also, while the weekly quizzes were annoying at the time, they definitely helped reinforce the concepts and made studying for the final much easier. 

I thought that this course was often weak in terms of organization and clarity of lectures. While Professor Irish was generally good at explaining information, the slides often seemed to lack content or be repetitive and thus did not help the learning process.
Poorly organized, not enough support.

The strengths of the course were that a lot of material was covered. One of the biggest weaknesses was the lack of organization and contradictions provided by the professor. There were times where the lectures didnt make sense or the teacher confused the students by saying I correct terms. This happened quite often and really was not helpful.

I think the paper was a really bad 5 part assignment. Students were all over the place trying to understand how to propose a proper research hypothesis for something so specific and I feel like it ended up detracting from the learning. I think what would have been better is if we were assigned to find and read a few papers on our own and then present their findings instead. I learned more from the papers I read during the assignment, than going through all the work of formulating a research question/hypothesis.
I think the quizzes are a strength but they are pretty difficult considering that theyre weakly assignments and are given in a very short time constraint.
Poor explanations of the material. The lecture did not help to prepare for quiz material.

I think the strength of this course is the problem sets and other assignments that force you to think about the research process and ask you to apply some of the material learned in lecture. I think the weaknesses are the supplemental materials and lectures that really don't provide lots of information or aren't super engaging.

The strength of the course was that there were weekly quizzes to keep us on top of the material. However, there were much more weaknesses than strengths. One of the many weaknesses was that there was WAYYYY too much homework every week: I spent an average of 18 hours (no exaggeration) on Biol 103 homework, which didn't even help me learn anything and felt very pointless. Another weakness is that we flew through the material so quickly during lecture that questions remained unanswered and explanations remained unclear. Furthermore, we were given inadequate time to complete the quizzes and final exam: many of my classmates and I did not even finish, even though we knew the material.
The homework. I did not like how we had to write a paper because it did not allow me to strengthen my knowledge of the material taught in class.
Give practice exam an quizzes.
Weaknesses: theyll ask you questions like which of these do you think is correct and then theyll grade it based on which ones for sure have to be right

The slides are terrible and lead to a very confusing presentation of the material. The material is presented very vaguely and often incorrectly, and was not at all preparative for the quizzes. The quizzes were incredibly unfair and fast paced, and seemed like they were trying to trick you to get you to lose points. While I understand the point of the homework, the way in which it is presented makes it so that students have to spend inordinate amounts of time on it. It is incredibly frustrating and time consuming and I saw many people cry because of this class.
I learned so much in the class.
The homework assignments were often confusing and would have appreciated practice tests for the exam. The slides are often not very helpful either.

Strong preparation to hunk like a scientist and the different experimental methods to use in science. In terms of the material, I felt we went very in depth with very specific examples of developmental processes, and I didnt get an overall overview.
Quizzes were very different from material presented.
Although I enjoyed the content of the class, I did not enjoy the homework assignments. I thought that they were much harder than necessary. The third assignment was rather annoying.
Strengths- the content was very interesting and material was engaging/ fascinating.

The class was honestly not great. It was pretty badly taught, the  slides kinda looked like they were made by a toddler using WordArt from Microsoft Powerpoint 1998, the quiz questions were very specific, and the homework took an offensive amount of time to complete. Worst of the bio modules by far.
It is not lectured too well. The supplementary info ends up being much better than the lectures.
Good lectures. Could have less work.
One strength was informative sections. One weakness was that it was sometimes difficult to pay attention during lecture.

Lecture slides were either bare of text that explained the figures on each slide, so it was very necessary to dependent on my own notes when reviewing the material. However, the lectures themselves were rushed and disorganized, so it was difficult to keep track of and synthesize the concepts being taught. Overall , the weakest part of this course was how the content of this course was organized (e.i how the concepts were presented in lecture, how the material on the lecture study guides were a poor reflection of the content covered on the quizzes, and Professor Irish's failure to point out the importance/ relevance of the concepts to the overarching themes of the course).
Lectures were very poorly organized and the homework assignments were unstructured and not helpful. I felt extremely lost without making time to meet with the peer tutors and my ta.
The homeowork assignments were stupid and tedious and had nothing to do with the course content.
The slides need more words especially when taking random figures from textbooks as going back and studying was difficult without any context on a slide.

Professor Irish and Dr. Lin are amazing instructors and mentors! So dedicated, so thoughtful, so accessible, and so approachable. I really believe that the instruction for this class has more clarity of information than I've experienced with any other STEM class. The class resources, including Piazza, canvas, and the peer tutors, are also really helpful for studying for tests and exploring concepts on a deeper level.
The material is very interesting, and Professor Irish is a good lecturer. The slides could be a bit more informative and include more words and descriptions instead of just images.

It was rather challenging to have a lecture then be expected to apply the concepts to reading a paper without fully understanding those concepts. Going into section felt very confusing and although we talked about concepts from the class in section, coming out of section gave me only a better awareness of how a concept was present in the paper instead of what the concept is in itself.

I liked the papers in the discussion section a lot! The problem set was not my favorite. And I appreciate the weekly quiz model for learning/practice's sake, but it was frustrating because I never did well with the time pressure / sometimes unexpected details, so despite doing well on the final I didn't do particularly well in the class. I think doing one less question, or five more minutes would be more fair. Overall, I found the subject matter interesting, and this was my favorite so far of the intro biology sequence

Weaknesses: not enough about genetics - the second half of the course felt rushed and glossed over; development focused on super specific examples of developmental processes, and then on the quizzes we were expected to anticipate how a great change would affect the process in a way that would not be intuitive as we only learned very particular details of the process (for instance, the one test question about what would happen if bicoid was absent from the embryo and then injected into the area where nanos was present and a head would form - we hadn't learned about how bicoid and nanos interact with each other); psets were very restrictive in what we could do but then also didn't give a lot of direction in terms of what to write; discussion sections didn't go over material from class - would have been more helpful than papers; quizzes too long for the time allotted (unable to fully think about the questions in many instances and the 'true/false but write an explanation either way' were odd and often difficult to interpret).
Strengths: interesting videos included in lectures; discussion of research techniques provide practical applications; while I think there is room for improvement in how the grant proposal homework is delivered, the idea of having us write a grant proposal is a good one.

Strengths: weekly quizzes

Weaknesses: Weekly homework assignments were tedious, annoying, and unhelpful in learning the material
Strengths: Lecture slides were clear and straightforward; Weaknesses: lack of practice problems for both weekly quizzes and final exam

Strengths- much better organized, lecture had good flow, conceptually wasn't overwhelming
Weaknesses- often, concepts were explained in an overly complicated manner that at times seemed deliberately opaque or required background scientific knowledge that not every member of the class possessed. Per usual, the history behind most of the discoveries made was centered around White men and neglected to center the viewpoints of people of color. For example, the epigenetics lecture would have been a perfect place to discuss environmental trauma due to racism and sexism, but not much was said.

This course is good as an intro for someone with minimal background in biology and research. For such a student, being walked through the different resources available (e.g. PubMed) and the process of writing a proposal would be very helpful. Unfortunately, this also means that a lot of the work is a bit tedious for those who already have experience writing research proposals or who already have a fair amount of background in biology.
It is very clearly made to be more difficult than necessary to make it harder to do well for the distribution. The content itself is interesting but presented pretty poorly.

The course felt rushed---I felt like there was a lot of information to unpack in both development and genetics, and due to the nature of the course, I felt as though I learned never learned any of the concepts deeply enough to really understand the individual concepts covered. I could explain each idea superficially, but I would not be able to answer most in-depth questions about the course material. I also strongly disliked the fact that we received no practice questions for the exams and quizzes--I personally think it would have been good practice material for me to better understand the lecture material. Plus the homework (which in previous classes was used to reinforce lecture concepts) was instead dedicated to teaching students about writing a scientific proposal, so outside of individual studying for assessments, students received little opportunity to practice their understanding of this type of biology.

There are pretty much no strengths of this course. However, it has plenty of weaknesses. For example, the peer tutors did not know what they were talkign about, and the professors and TAs were not available for office hours nor for questions. The course brushed over a lot of concepts at such a basic level that I did not feel like I gained anything from this course.

This course was strong in that Professor Lin was there every step of the way to help students clarify concepts and make the experience easier, but the weakness was that the course was very fast-paced.

There needs to be more guidance for the homework.  Instead of psets, each homework assignment was one part of a grant proposal.  I really enjoyed the thinking and research required to design a worthwhile experiment; however, the expectations from my TA were higher than what I could reach given the tools I was given.  It seemed like my TA expected me to understand and use biological techniques I had never used of in my proposal.  No matter what I did with the resources available to me, it never was enough for my TA.  The requirement for sources was 2-3 for just the introduction section.  I had 8 sources to support my various claims, but somehow my TA told me that I should do even broader research.  This was absurd not only considering that the expectation was about 3 sources but also considering that the page limit was 1 page.  This pattern of high expectations not matching what was presented on the direction with a small page limit considering what was expected continues throughout the writing process.  I think it depends largely on your TA, but my gosh this class is the reason I got sick the first few weeks of school.
I think the structure of the quizzes was poor. It felt like there wasn't enough time devoted to these, and they made up a disproportionate amount of the course grade.

The homework series was fantastic, cultivating into a great final research paper. The content made complex processes a lot easier to understand. I did think it focused too much on model organisms. I really wanted to learn and visualize human development and was disappointed to learn mostly about fruit flies and mice (even though they undergo the same development and it's easier to use model organisms).

Some points in lecture were tough to follow, this could be circumvented by a higher pace to pack in more background information for the question being investigated, jargon, etc. Clarifying the details essentially. This calls for putting out more info in the same amount of time, but doing so may allow for an overall higher absorption of info by students given a clearer picture.

I don't like the weekly quiz format. 15 minutes is such a short period of time to solve biological problems, and I found it extremely difficult to improve my quiz grades no matter how much I studied or attended peer tutoring. I think the format of a midterm and a final would maybe be better.

The course deals with a fascinating aspect of biology because genetics is something everyone can relate to, and it explains so much of who we are. I did not find the weekly quizzes to be useful at all, however. They are not so good at measuring your understanding, but rather your reading and writing speed.

I'd recommend 103 in the fall more than 103 in the spring, just based on my experience shopping 103b and then taking 103a. Professor Irish is a very good lecturer and also really enthusiastic about helping students. The material is also really interesting. I would just be mindful of the fact that the course is a lot of work.
Yes, it is a good course.
Will definitely recommend it if you are interested in the topic.

If you're considering taking this course, you most likely are required to take it. I would not recommend any part of the BIOL sequence for non-science majors or people with merely a passing interest in biology. I would however, strongly recommend the spring sequence (this one) over the sequence starting in the fall in terms of pace, instructors, manageability, and class learning environment.

I wouldn't say this course was particularly fun or extremely engaging (except for the sex determination lecture, which was very cool) simply because there wasn't enough time to go into detail on the interesting topics we brushed on, so I'd probably just take this is if you need it to take higher level MCDB courses (or are pre-med, I guess).
The content is interesting. However, the quizzes and homework assignments are very demanding in terms of workload.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in gaining a foundation in developmental biology or in genetics. It has very interesting course material and while the concepts may be tricky, it is still worthwhile to learn them.
I would recommend to pre-med or biology majors or students who want an introduction to genetics and development to see if it interests them.
I would recommend this course as an introduction to some topics in biology. For a student who wants a superficial understanding of genetics or development, this course would be well suited for them.

You probably need to take Biol 103 anyways, and I think this course was much more difficult than the other previous intro biology modules, this was pretty well taught overall. I would definitely recommend staying on top of the material, as you cover a lot very quickly, and it might be hard to catch up later as the topics build on each other.
Yes but only if required

I think that most people who take this course are pre-meds or biology majors, so it's kind of necessary. But, I think the new ways of thinking this class emphasizes are crucial in developing biological and experimental critical thinking skills. It's not as painful and difficult as people make it out to be. The class can be fun if you see the material (development and genetics) in a new light!
Yes if you have to take it. It requires consistent, hard work.
Yes - it gives a solid foundation for any sort of pursuit in biology.
No, the course has a lot of homework and the quizzes are unfair. Do not take it unless you are pre-med.

It was a good way to get familiar with developmental biology and genetics topics but I wouldnt recommend this course to someone with no bio experience even though this is supposed to be an intro course because it does move pretty quickly.

This course is a very full lecture as it is a prerequisite for many majors as well as premed so I am sure it needs recommendation. I believe the off sequence classes were wonderfully taught especially in comparison to what i have heard from friends about the on sequence classes.

I wouldn't recommend taking this course unless it's required for your major/future academic interests. As much as the teaching quality is fine, the content is boring and focuses too much on research methods considering it's mostly pre-med students, not future researchers, taking the class.
Pretty good experience overall. The proposal involved a lot of research and reading, but it was fun I guess
Yes, it's a prerequisite for many upper level MCDB classes, so it should be taken by students in the major
yes
Not really unless you need to take it. It's fine as part of the intro bio sequence but it's not a super engaging course if you dont need to take it.
no - it is hard to feel like this course wants students to succeed. I felt that class time and section did not prepare students for quizzes and there was insufficient time for quiz taking

I would recommend if you want to learn more about certain subsets of genetics and development. If you're required to take this course, it's not bad. It is hampered by the problem of all the introductory biology courses in that it is, well, very introductory. We only learn a small subset about genetics and while it is a good primer, I think that learning a broader swathe of genetics and development would be very useful.
I would recommend this course to any biology majors and people who are interested in learning about developmental biology and genetics.
Take it only if you have to take it. The quizzes are full of poorly conceived and trick questions and the homeworks will make you want to drop the course.
Sure, most people in the class take it because they need to.
No

Yes, especially because it is only half a semester course. It was interesting, and although it may not have been my favorite of the Bio modules, I did learn a lot from it. It was a lot of work however and the psets took me an incredibly long amount of time.
It is part of the bio sequence, so many STEM majors need it. Do not take it just for. SC credit however.
I would recommend it to anyone who is a biology major.
Yes.
Most people taking this have to take it for a requirement, if it's not a requirement it's probably not worth the workload, especially with the research proposal project.
Contrary to what others seem to think, I believe that the intro bio sequence is well taught and very interesting. Weekly quizzes are hard, so definitely study.

Most students in this class have to take it as a prerequisite--if this does not apply to you, I would not recommend taking the course. I think that while the course material is interesting and expansive, there are equally good classes that offer the same exposure for non-biology majoring students interested in a taste of the material without the stress of the five week homework assignment.
Although it might be best to only take this class if you have to, it was definitely my favorite out of all the ones Ive taken in the bio sequence so far.
I would recommend this course to students who require it for a major or who are very passionate about biology.
You either have to take it or you don't. But I heard on sequence with prof zhong is worse, so go for this.
Yes, take it if you are interested in genetics and developmental bio.
I would definitely recommend this course to everyone, stem and humanity majors.
What
Not particularly... but students probably won't have another option.
Its mandatory so you dont have a choice if youre premed/a bio major.

I would but only because this course is required to take upper level biology courses. There was just a lot of disjoint at times that makes the course hard to follow, but if you have to take it you have to take it.
I would not recommend this course unless you are a premed or bio major. It was hard to access resources that made me feel like I was truly understanding the material.
I would only recommend this to those that require it for their major.
No not unless needed, not an enjoyable biology course, I liked topic but found I had to do all preparation for quiz on my own despite being involved and attending all lectures.
I wouldn't. The material may be interesting to some, but I just don't think the course was structured in such a way to make it engaging or accessible.
No, I would not recommend this course to another student. ONLY TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU ABSOLUTELY HAVE TO. Otherwise, it is a waste of your time and efforts.
If you have to take it, take it. The material is interesting , though.
Only if necessary.
This course teaches you things from a 6th grade level of understanding and then expects you to exert a college level of performance.

No. The slides are terrible and lead to a very confusing presentation of the material. The material is presented very vaguely and often incorrectly, and was not at all preparative for the quizzes. The quizzes were incredibly unfair and fast paced, and seemed like they were trying to trick you to get you to lose points. While I understand the point of the homework, the way in which it is presented makes it so that students have to spend inordinate amounts of time on it. It is incredibly frustrating and time consuming and I saw many people cry because of this class.
yes

I would in the sense that it is a requirement for medical school. Otherwise, I probably would not. The work itself was often unpleasant. I would say the material was somewhat interesting, but the way in which the assignments were organized was not exciting.
Yes, if it is a requirement is enjoyable but still a good introductory biology course.
I would recommend this class to another student to learn basics in genetics and development.
This is a good course to take to learn what developmental biology is about and whether you might've be interested n pursuing it further.
No, not unless you have to take it.
Unless there are majoring in a science, no.
Yes. Great course and prof!
Yes, I this course gives a great foundation in genetics and developmental biology.
No.
Only take it if you have to.

Yes! I would recommend this course to another student who is seeking a strong foundational basic science/biology background. The concepts presented here are critical to understanding the development of life, and this course does a great job of introducing concepts with clarity.
Yes if the subject material is interesting to you/you need it as a pre-req for something.

If you're taking Biol103, you're probably taking it because you have to. It's a good class that I learned from. I'm not sure I'd recommend spending 2 credits on the whole sequence if you don't need it at all (especially because it requires consistent work throughout the week, and the Biol103 HW especially can take a while) but I really do appreciate having a foundation in biology
Yes, it is interesting if you're interested in bio but the homework is annoying.
Yes
I mean you probably have to take it so take it but really dont do this to you if you dont
I didn't really have a particularly good time in this course, but I think it's important from the standpoint of foundational biology.

If you are considering taking this class, it's probably a requirement for your major. If it isn't and you're just looking for a science credit or a fun biology class, I'd recommend looking elsewhere. That being said, Professor Irish does a great job teaching the material and it's overall a decent course, particularly as an intro for someone with minimal background in biology and research. For such a student, being walked through the different resources available (e.g. PubMed) and the process of writing a proposal would be very helpful. Unfortunately, this also means that a lot of the work is a bit tedious for those who already have experience writing research proposals or who already have a fair amount of background in biology. All in all, if you have to take this course, taking it with Professor Irish is the way to go.
Not unless you need it.
Only if you need the course for a major or other requirement.
Absolutely not. Do not take this course unless you have to  it is taught badly, has no resources, and does not try to facilitate student learning.
I would recommend this course if you would like to be challenged and want to learn more about research methods in biology.
For a requirement, or if you have a particular interest in developmental biology.

I would recommend it, but only to people interested in animal development. I think it is too model organism oriented to be widely enjoyed by anyone interested to learn about embryo and fetus development.

I would only recommend this class to someone who needs it for their major or pre-professional track. It's not a bad class by any means, but I don't think this class would be enjoyable unless you have a specific interest in biology.
